image.altText: A designed image showing Malcolm Turnbull gesturing with his finger and Barnaby Joyce  looking downcast.

props.synopsis: The former merchant banker and bush accountant enjoyed an unlikely but successful political partnership. That all changed when Malcolm Turnbull strode into his courtyard and denounced Barnaby Joyce in front of the nation over his affair with a staffer, Vikki Campion.

title.children: 'I just saw him as an idiot': Barnaby Joyce on the moment Malcolm Turnbull denounced his affair

image.altText: Harry Dannock in karate uniform.

props.synopsis: Harry was 10 when clenching his fists during karate classes became difficult. But the real turning point came when he asked his mum and dad to stop hugging him because it hurt too much.

title.children: Tasmanian children waiting months be diagnosed with juvenile arthritis due to lack of specialists

image.altText: Inside of a shopping mall at Christmas time. Unsplash.

props.synopsis: A raft of official economic data suggests Australia's economy suddenly hit a wall in December. Is the data wrong, or did the Reserve Bank raise rates one time too many in November?

title.children: 'Did the Australian economy just snap'? It may be 'unlikely' but it's looking more and more possible

image.altText: A composite image of Leonard O'Meara and a drone shot of his house in Derby, WA.

props.synopsis: There are calls for an ASIC investigation after an Indigenous pensioner was charged an annual insurance premium of almost $10,000 by QBE for an asbestos-clad home in a remote town in Western Australia.

title.children: Calls for investigation after pensioner charged $54k for home insurance on 'asbestos cottage'

image.altText: Kate Selway working in glacial wind

props.synopsis: Kate Selway has spent the past two months battling subzero temperatures, perpetual sunlight, and getting stuck on the ice to help unlock the secrets of Antarctica’s melting glaciers.

title.children: Kate spent summer in Antarctica. This is what it’s like to live in one of the most remote places on Earth

image.altText: A man and woman stand next to a 1.3 metre tall statue in case.

props.synopsis: The statue stands at 1.3 metres tall and was donated to the Maritime Museum of Tasmania, after spending much of its existence hidden from view in a private home.

title.children: Functionally plumbed statue of man urinating a significant find for Tasmanian museum

image.altText: Floral tributes for a deceased man.

props.synopsis: The young man who drowned during an alleged robbery last month is mourned by hundreds at a vigil in Hobart — with a special thank you to those who tried in vain to save him.

title.children: 'Shattered our hearts': Young drowning victim remembered at Hobart vigil

image.altText: A police officer stands by an escalator with blue and white police tap around it.

props.synopsis: Police are reviewing CCTV footage of the incident, which a detective described as "extremely confronting to watch", and calling for members of the public to come forward if they have any information.

title.children: Grandmother dies after being stabbed in the chest during 'abhorrent, cowardly' attack at shopping centre west of Brisbane

image.altText: A pop art illustration of a woman wearing sunglasses, with thumbs up emojis in the glass.

props.synopsis: Human preoccupation with beauty has a long history, but these experts say something new is at play.

title.children: Beautiful people are better liked, richer and more successful. Two philosophers explain why

image.altText: LeBron James standing on court during an NBA game between the Lakers and Rockets.

props.synopsis: After sparking speculation over his playing future, LeBron James provides a one-word answer when asked whether he has spent time thinking about his upcoming contract decision.

title.children: LeBron James tight-lipped about Lakers future following cryptic social media post

image.altText: A graphic showing a man coughing, a rapid antigen COVID test and three spike proteins

props.synopsis: Behind the scenes governments have been steadily dismantling many other elements of a surveillance system that we were so reliant on in the emergency period of the COVID-19 pandemic, writes Casey Briggs.

title.children: If you've tried to look up COVID cases recently, you'll have noticed something has changed

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed with a serious look on his face with th Hard quiz logo in the top left corner

props.synopsis: So, you think you're good at quizzes but don't have the guts to front up to my actual TV show? Well, try this then.

title.children: Hard Quiz: You better believe I'm here to judge you. Let's play HARD!

image.altText: A young woman in a three-piece suit and handcuffs is escorted by a man and a woman

props.synopsis: Fifty years ago, a teenaged heiress with a famous last name was kidnapped from her California apartment by armed terrorists. What followed was one of the most confounding crimes in American history.

title.children: This kidnapped heiress-turned-revolutionary was despised in America. Then a Hollywood star spoke out

image.altText: A silhouette stature of a man holding a spear in front of a sunset.

props.synopsis: John Pat's death at just 16 inside an outback police lock-up sparked national outrage and a royal commission. Forty years later, what is his legacy in his hometown?

title.children: The shocking death of a 16-year-old in police custody 40 years ago continues to reverberate in this outback town

image.altText: A man pours a bucket of water on a burning building.

props.synopsis: At least 46 people have been killed by wildfires in Chile with the death toll expected to rise.

title.children: Raging forest fires kill at least 46 in Chile; toll expected to rise

image.altText: Matthew Farrell smiles looking at the camera while sitting in the cockpit of a small aeroplane.

props.synopsis: The fiancée of a man who died when his light plane crashed in the Victorian High Country believes he was let down by the system and was not given adequate training to be a safe and competent pilot.

title.children: Coroner's inquiry questions whether recreational pilot was adequately trained before fatal flight

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A large bird, with a white head and grey wings sits among mangroves on a lake.

props.synopsis: Chris Tippett says he has helped small birds and even pelicans before but a large eagle presented a bigger challenge. With no trained specialists available, he called on people power.

title.children: Wounded eagle rescue restores vet's faith in people after residents rally in lieu of experts

image.altText: Mole Hill Fantasy Postcard Scan

props.synopsis: Many Tasmanians fondly remember Mole Hill Fantasy — a popular 1980-90s attraction for locals and tourists alike. We look into what happened to it.

title.children: Visitors loved 'the little world of little moles'. We found out what happened to the holiday park diorama

image.altText: Farmer stands in a wide field under a cloudy sky.

props.synopsis: The issues that led to the royal commission five years ago have faded, even if they haven't all been fixed. As new issues like scams and the impact of artificial intelligence capture attention, advocates want banks to keep a focus on doing the right thing by their customers.

title.children: Charging dead people, stealing billions — the five years that cleaned up banking

image.altText: Two women stand in a parliamentary lobby wearing semi-formal attire, smiling.

props.synopsis: Jude Hudson was whisked away to give birth in a home for unwed mothers in her mid-teens, then her baby girl was taken from her. She may now be entitled to compensation for Victorian mothers forced to put their children up for adoption.

title.children: Mother separated from daughter for 18 years among first to apply for Australian-first redress scheme

image.altText: Joko Widido left shakes hands with a crowd of supporters next to his son who is also greeting people.

props.synopsis: Less than a fortnight out from Indonesia's election, President Joko Widodo's son is proving to be the decisive factor driving some of the country's almost 200 million voters towards his joint ticket. Could he secure the Widodo political dynasty?

title.children: With the possible rise of a nepo baby, Widodo went from anti-dynasty candidate to kingmaker

image.altText: Two women pose while making videos on TikTok highlighting their legs

props.synopsis: A social media trend encouraging women and girls to compare the look of their legs in leggings has been prompted warnings from experts and led to the associated hashtag being banned on TikTok.

title.children: What is the 'legging legs' trend, and why has the hashtag been blocked by TikTok?

image.altText: A group of children hold out empty pots and containers.

props.synopsis: Signs of a Hamas resurgence in the Gaza Strip's largest city underscore the group's resilience despite Israel's deadly air and ground campaign against it over the past four months.

title.children: Hamas deploys police forces, makes payments to civil servants in Gaza City

image.altText: A group of US soldiers in camouflage uniform carry a flag-draped metal case out of an airplane.

props.synopsis: The US military says the US carried out retaliatory air strikes in Iraq and Syria against more than 85 targets linked to Iran's Revolutionary Guard and the militias they back.

title.children: 'If you harm an American, we will respond': US conducts strikes in Iraq and Syria, killing 39

image.altText: A man in a black suit, holds up a woman in a gold dress who is doing the splits

props.synopsis: A successful viral hoax generated a lot of buzz for star-studded campy action comedy Argylle. Does it live up to the hype?

title.children: If nothing else, Argylle is a testament to the magic of movie marketing

image.altText: Danielle Scott react after winning silver at the World Cup aerial skiing event in Deer Valley.

props.synopsis: Danielle Scott and Abbey Willcox claim medals at the famous World Cup event in Deer Valley, while fellow Australian Cam Bolton enjoys a return to form in the snowboard cross in Europe.

title.children: Aussie aerial skiers reach the podium at prestigious US World Cup event

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt and vest sits next to a woman in dark black conservative Islamic garb behind a table.

props.synopsis: A Pakistan court has sentenced former prime minister Imran Khan to a further seven years in prison along with his wife, after a ruling that their 2018 marriage violated the law.

title.children: Former Pakistan PM Imran Khan and his wife get seven-year sentences for unlawful marriage

image.altText: Two-storey white house.

props.synopsis: If you're buying a home that has been "substantially renovated" you may have to pay GST. The problem home buyers face is that what qualifies as a "substantial renovation" is uncertain, writes Christine Peacock.

title.children: Buying a renovated home? You could be up for an extra 10 per cent GST, but it's a grey area

image.altText: A cover of a board game with hands playing .

props.synopsis: Squatter started out as a side hustle and turned into one of the most successful Australian board games ever.

title.children: The 1960s Aussie board game that has sold 700,000 copies

image.altText: Megan Schutt's teammates gather around her to celebrate a wicket

props.synopsis: Australian quick Megan Schutt celebrates her milestone match with a miserly spell in an eight-wicket thumping of South Africa in the series-opening women's one-day international.

title.children: Australia cruises to victory over South Africa in first ODI in Adelaide

image.altText: Luay Sako leaves a prison van, dressed in grey clothing.

props.synopsis: More than three years on, the family of Celeste Manno remain in disbelief that she was murdered by an intruder wielding a knife and a hammer in the middle of the night.

title.children: In a Melbourne court, the horror of 'bogeyman' killer Luay Sako's crime was laid bare

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses walks surrounded by people.

props.synopsis: The operator of a jumping castle that killed six children after being lifted into the air pleads not guilty to a related safety charge in a northern Tasmanian court.

title.children: Profanity hurled at Hillcrest jumping castle operator after she pleads not guilty

image.altText: A man holds a bunch of bridles.

props.synopsis: Tasracing bans Tasmania's leading harness racing trainer from entry to the state's racetracks, two days after the release of a major independent report into race fixing.

title.children: Ben Yole banned from attending future races after race-fixing report's adverse findings

image.altText: a coastal area where a wooden structure has been built

props.synopsis: Frustrated with a lack of government action, the residents of this coastal paradise constructed their own sea walls to slow coastal erosion. But authorities claim the ad hoc builds sometimes make erosion worse and need to be removed.

title.children: Parks to remove 'unauthorised' sea walls that make coastal erosion 'worse'
